title: Which WW2 submachine gun do gun enthusiasts rate the most highly? - Quora

response.answer_text: The PPs-43. While the PPSh-41 became much more iconic, the PPs-43 was simply a better weapon. The 41 was an alright weapon, but it had some pretty serious drawbacks. Chief amongst them was that it’s rate of fire was just too high. It was very easy for the weapon to become uncontrollable and empty even the drum magazine very quickly. Most of those shots would hit nothing. Adding to that, the iconic drum magazines were really not very good. They required extensive hand fitting to function at all, and even then were tied to one gun. They were difficult to load, heavy, expensive and always had reliability issues, and so were quickly replaced with stick magazines, which thereby negated the PPSh-41s ammo capacity advantages. Soldiers could carry more stick magazines than drums, so their total ammo load was actually higher with the stick magazines anyway. The PPSh was also quite heavy for what it was, coming in at 8lbs. While this is lighter than the Thompson, and about the same as the inexplicably heavy MP-40, it was still 1.5–2lbs heavier than the PPs-43. The PPs-43 also had a folding stock, making it a much more compact weapon, so it was just all around a lot easier to carry. What really killed the PPSh, however, was that it was rather expensive and took quite a while to manufacture owing to it’s extensive use of milled parts. The PPs-43 could be manufactured in half the time with half the steel. It was a simple stamped steel gun, but it worked, and that’s all it needed to do. Notice how I haven’t mentioned accuracy. That’s because for a SMG, it really doesn’t matter. All SMGs are close combat weapons, and so the mechanical accuracy of a weapon is not much of a concern. These are weapons designed to engage out to about 100 yards max, and rapidly become ineffective beyond that. All in all, I’d say the PPs-43 was the ideal subgun of the war. It fired the powerful Tokarev round, it was controllable even in automatic fire, it was light and easy to carry, it was reliable, and more importantly, it could be churned out in vast numbers so every soldier that needed one, had one. It was a straight improvement over the old PPSh-41, and was well loved by Red Army soldiers.

Reading the other answers, it’s apparent that some people write and forward opinions, but they’ve NEVER fired those weapons because the comments are absurd if you have. The Thompson, much to my surprise, was crap. A War time Thompson has an appalling sight, like a blocky tombstone with a hole in it blocking much of your vision. The stock is awkward and there’s two reasons many photos show soldiers firing it holding it low and looking over the sights. The Thompson is a first generation submachinegun and it has all the faults and problems of such.    what species was that stock made for? I’d the great fortune of asking Dolf Goldsmith what his preferred submachinegun was, and he astonished me by saying the M3, the grease gun. Dolf Goldsmith is a reknown expert on automatic weapons, and he provided many of the weapons uses in movies through the 1960’s and 1970’s. Taking his advice, I went and fired the M3 and was delighted. Like the MP 40, it’s surprisingly controllable and it’s not inaccurate. I’ll defer to his preference on that, as significant people in the field, including Ian from Forgotten Weapons respects his opinion. I also listen carefully to what Ian says regarding firearms, his knowledge is incredible. Ian, however, would add his perspective on manufacture and features rather than simply which would you prefer to shoot. Side note, if you match up a decent magazine with a STEN, and it’s a decent STEN, it’s a pleasure to shoot. Properly held, you have your support hand under the receiver, not holding the magazine. One funny thing is I was surprised at how heavy the dang STEN felt, although other submachineguns are heavier. Perhaps it’s the utility design and the Spartan use of materials that gave me an impression it’d feel lighter, but I perceived it to be heavier than it was.

Frankly I’ll tell you up front gun enthusiasts will be very divided on this topic, with groups devoted to each SMG used in WWII making arguments for what’s the best. In this one gun enthusiasts personal opinion, I would rate most highly the Beretta Model 38 (MAB 38) style of SMG’s.  Designed and first produced in the opening years of the war, the Italians frankly made an ingenious design of creating a large, heavy sub machine gun designed to accept magazines ranging from 10–40 round capacity. It has a semi-automatic and fully-automatic setting, the latter being kept to a very controllable rate of fire (early models stood at roughly 600 rounds a minute with later models bumping down to as slow as 450 rounds a minute). It was considered very accurate, being able to hit targets on semi-automatic out to 200 meters. The Italians also created a “hot” 9x19mm round specifically designed to be shot out of the Model 38, extending the effective range of the weapon substantially. Finally, even as they had to remove features over time as Italy was invaded to keep producing them, quality of manufacturing the SMG did not drop substantially, with factories doggedly maintaining relatively high standards of production under wartime conditions, making sure the guns they sent out for use in the field would work provided the soldier didn’t neglect to give them basic cleaning or maintence when not using it in a firefight. Frankly, you know a weapon is popular when the Italians had trouble holding onto them, because Germans and various Allied soldiers grabbed these guns at every possible opportunity due to their positive feedback on the weapons capabilities and effectiveness in combat.

I got instructed to Suomi KP/31 and Sten Machine Carbine when I served in the Finnish military. Both were already then considered as weapons of secondary importance, as RK-62 was our main weapon anyway.  Both Suomi KP/31 and Sten employ the 9 mm Parabellum round. Of those two Suomi is far more accurate and reliable, but Sten appears to be more versatile and lighter. The fact that Sten is easier to shoot prone (doe to its port attached magazine) matters a lot. The Suomi KP can take either a box or round drum magazine. The Stens we had were modified by Kuopio arsenal to fit the Finnish requirements. As an engineer I would take the Sten with me on ordinary missions. Engineers are not supposed to get engaged in battle (if they do, they have done something wrong) and Sten is better for firing (or, should I say, spraying) suppressive fire before retreating and detaching off the firefight. But should I get engaged on assaults, crossing of waterways or actual need of bang-bang fight, Suomi KP would be my choice.

Its going to be controversial,but here goes. The gun that most gun enthusiasts rate highly is the M55 Reising.  M55 Reising First off,this is one of the most accurate .45ACP/.22lr carbines ever made,due to the fact that It came out of the factory with very tight tolerances,which usually translates into better overall accuracy. Secondly,its dirt cheap for a class 3 full-auto firearm,costing a mere $5000 on gunbroker. https://www.gunbroker.com/All/BI.aspx?Keywords=reising For comparison,a M16 with full auto capabilites will set you back a cool $30,000 Rock Island Auction: Colt - M16 This puts It in the price range of any ordinary gun enthusiast who wants to own and expirence an automatic firearm,but doesn’t have 30,000 on hand to spare. And despite its reliability issues in jungle combat,as stated by Wikipedia: .. the Reising's close tolerance and delicate magazine proved unreliable in the sand and mud of the Solomons—unless kept scrupulously clean. -M50 Reising - Wikipedia The gun for the most part,runs fine,unless you decide to not maintain It for whatever personal reasons you may have. Sure,disassembly is more difficult than other sub machine guns of its time,but in the modern day,all those issues are negiligable. Its a great civilian weapon,and thus,I’m surprised that the Resising hasn’t been supportes en masse. That’s all folks!

For actually shooting, a Thompson. Easily the most accurate and controllable on full auto out of the bunch, and it had a lot better fit and finish than your stamped guns. But they’re heavy, awkward pigs: they weighed 11 pounds and had all kinds of parts sticking out at odd angles, and they were very expensive. The Army started trying to replace them pretty quickly after they were fielded, because their actual utility didn’t justify the cost. The MP40 was probably the best all around: heavy, but very well finished for a stamped gun and very controllable. And they got quite compact if the stock was folded and the magazine was removed; German vehicle crews loved them for this. The PPSHs are very crude and difficult to handle. You can’t even see the sights while you’re shooting it, because the spent cases and muzzle flame gets in the way. They’re the epitome of spray and pray. The Owen and Beretta submachine guns were well liked by their users, but I’ve never heard of any modern-day shooters who’ve fired one.

The three best SMG’s of WWII was the Suomi KP-31, Beretta Modello 38 and the Owen. The Sten was more or less an good example of that you get what you pay for and for the most part a lousy one. The irony of it is that the Brits after the war turned the lousy Sten into the excellent Sterling but that was after the hostilities. MP-40 was a good and cheap SMG but not the best, the PPsH-41 was also good but a bit crude but with a potent 7,62 x 25mm round and a high rate of fire. The Thompson was an excellent gun until it met up with wartime conditions, too heavy and too complicated with narrow civilian tolerances in the mechanism. A fact that continued with the M1A1. The best of the crude simplified ones was the PPS-43.

That depends on the enthusiast group. But generally the two highest are normally the MP-40 and the PPSH-41. The sten and the m3 were both lower quality subguns, the Thompson was heavy and hard to control, and both the Italian ( MAB 38) and Japanese (type 100) subguns usually get forgotten. So, it’s down to the German and Soviet designs most of the time.

The trouble is everyone has their favourite and no one answer is more correct than others but I find the most numerous and very effective was the Sten gun. Now I am sure there will be the inevitable claims the Sten was unreliable and inaccurate as well as dangerous. Some of this is true but the Sten was light, easy to strip and clean and very cheap to make, in fact of the many millions made a lot of them were made by the Resistance in occupied countries and even Germany copied and made many thousands of them. A well cared for Sten proved to be very good and unlike the very expensive Thompson more useful.

Rate highly for what? Firepower? Looks? Accuracy? Or what? For me it would be the Sturmgewehr 44 assault rifle. It really was groundbreaking - and it’s an awesome looking weapon. And although it was by far not the best submachine pistol on the market the iconic MP-40 is the sexiest submachine gun on the battlefield. Have fired them a few times and really got my rocks off. Back in the day, off course. Not anymore.

PPS43 Redirect Notice 7.62x25 Tokarev gets 200 METERS out of this gun. 9 and 45 SMG’s to this day? 50M at most.Very inexpensive and easy to produce.Easy to control and very reliable, a perfect weapon for urban fighting.Weighs only 7 pounds, a lot less than its competitors that were 10–16 pounds (Glares at Thompson)

Here in the UK I would say that the most collectable (deactivated) WWII SMG would be any variant of the MP38/40 followed by the Thompson, however many experts would probably rate the Finnish Suomi KP31 as one of the most influential designs of the war.

Sturmgewehr 44- The worlds first assult rifle. Excellent weapon! It could fire single shot, semi auto, full auto. It was a war winner but for years Hitler and The German General staff yes men had no interest in the weapon? The manufacturners made it in secret behind Hitlers back, and once he saw how good it was he’d OK it. It is the as the jet fighter? The Germans could have fought the Battle of Britain with jet’s , but Hitler and Goering had no interst in jet technology?

if you play any ww2 fps set in european theatre you'll easily fell in love with mp40. why? because it probably the first smg you ever had in the game, making mp40 very well known. the next may be ppsh-41. being an smg with 71 bullets carrying more bulletr than any other smg, make it well known to all ww2 enthusiasts.

This is my favorite simply because my grandfather (a master gunsmith who had the correct license) had one. MP 40 - Wikipedia I did get to fire it but I was probably 15 at the time. I just remember it as thrill. So my answer is more about my memories than some logical ranking of the various possible choices.
It seems recently there’s been increased appreciation for the US submachine gun, caliber 45, M-3. Not as good as the Korea-era M3A1, and certainly no thing of beauty, but quite functional.
If you went to try but one, a transferable Thompson M1A1 Submachine Gun will cost you at least $20,000. Most the other WW2 submachine guns can be bought for less than that.
I’ll let Ian “The Gun Jesus” and his disciple Karl the Walking Gun Platform to bear witness about Suomi KP/31:
I would take the M2 carbine over any 9mm weapon. So you say the M2 is not a submachine gun? It does fire an attenuated cartridge.

For failsafe reliability or as an investment? The Swedish K or the Suomi are good, the Sten was bulletproof but lacked a safety, the Thompson and Schmeisser are worth big bucks and the GM Grease Gun is nice, albeit with a rather slow fire rate.. I like the PPSH 41.
The StG 44 sub machine gun. A beautifully designed, reliable weapon, which could also be used in a single shot mode. The Russians later based the AK 47 on it.
The M1A1 Thompson. It is powerful fast firing and reliable.
